Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Modifying Chitin Nanofibers for Freeze-cast Biomaterials with Hierarchical Structure

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction

This East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) in Japan for FY 2011 award provided Amalie Donius of Drexel University the opportunity to take part in an orientation for EAPSI fellows.  Full support of A. Donius' proposed research project at Kyoto University in Japan was recieved in FY 2012.  The graduate student, A. Donius, was hosted by Professor Hiroyuki Yano and his laboratory in the summer of 2012. The research findings, intellectual merit, and broader impacts of this research experience follow.

 

Research Findings

The overall goal of this research was to test the hypothesis that the functionality of highly porous biomaterials with fully dense cell walls could be enhanced by creating porous cell walls with additional nanoporosity. The second level of porosity and greater functionality in the porous material was created through the use of cellulose or chitin nanofibers, in which the surface can be functionalized. Objectives culminating in this goal were investigated.  The first objective was to successfully separate nanofibers from wood pulp and chitin.  Series of mechanical and chemical treatments of cellulose wood pulp and chitin resulted in the extrusion of cellulose and chitin nanofibers, respectively.  Additionally, chitin nanofibers were further treated to functionalize the surface.  These nanofibers were imaged with scanning electron microscopy and analyzed with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction.  The second objective was to fabricate films of several chosen compositions of these nanofibers.  The third objective of this research was to analyze and characterize these films mechanically and structurally.  This enables for the selection of the optimal material, which composes the cell walls of highly porous biomaterials.

 

Intellectual Merit

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in the fabrication of porous degradable and resorbable biomaterials from environmentally benign and biocompatible materials. In addition to the macroporosity of the porous material, the cell wall composition and arrangement plays a large role in the mechanical performance and functionality of the material.  This was therefore investigated in an attempt to determine optimal biopolymer nanofiber-reinforced wall materials.

 

Broader Impacts

Through the EAPSI fellowship, an international collaboration between Professor Dr. Hiroyuki Yano at Kyoto University, Japan, and graduate student Amalie Donius at Drexel University, USA was forged.  Interactions within Prof. Yano’s laboratory at Kyoto University with scientists at all levels served as an unparalleled experience in which the fellow gained a better appreciation of the research environment, research community, and scientific policies of Japan.  The fellow experienced the research culture and the spirit of innovation and precision in science, for which the Japanese are known.  The introduction to the Japanese society, culture, and language through cultural activities proved to be unforgettable; old traditions going back to long before our country was founded, harmoniously present in the modern society.

This research on cellulose and chitin nanofiber-reinforced materials contributes to an understanding of biopolymer reinforcement and the design of new hierarchically-structured materials from biopolymers. The results are furthermore expected to contribute to structure-property correlations for the design of porous materials with a hierarchical structure, such as those used in ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Introduction This East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) in Japan for FY 2011 award provided Amalie Donius of Drexel University the opportunity to take part in an orientation for EAPSI fellows. Full support of A. Donius' proposed research project at Kyoto University in Japan was recieved in FY 2012. The graduate student, A. Donius, was hosted by Professor Hiroyuki Yano and his laboratory in the summer of 2012. The research findings, intellectual merit, and broader impacts of this research experience follow. Research Findings The overall goal of this research was to test the hypothesis that the functionality of highly porous biomaterials with fully dense cell walls could be enhanced by creating porous cell walls with additional nanoporosity. The second level of porosity and greater functionality in the porous material was created through the use of cellulose or chitin nanofibers, in which the surface can be functionalized. Objectives culminating in this goal were investigated. The first objective was to successfully separate nanofibers from wood pulp and chitin. Series of mechanical and chemical treatments of cellulose wood pulp and chitin resulted in the extrusion of cellulose and chitin nanofibers, respectively. Additionally, chitin nanofibers were further treated to functionalize the surface. These nanofibers were imaged with scanning electron microscopy and analyzed with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction. The second objective was to fabricate films of several chosen compositions of these nanofibers. The third objective of this research was to analyze and characterize these films mechanically and structurally. This enables for the selection of the optimal material, which composes the cell walls of highly porous biomaterials. Intellectual Merit The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in the fabrication of porous degradable and resorbable biomaterials from environmentally benign and biocompatible materials. In addition to the macroporosity of the porous material, the cell wall composition and arrangement plays a large role in the mechanical performance and functionality of the material. This was therefore investigated in an attempt to determine optimal biopolymer nanofiber-reinforced wall materials. Broader Impacts Through the EAPSI fellowship, an international collaboration between Professor Dr. Hiroyuki Yano at Kyoto University, Japan, and graduate student Amalie Donius at Drexel University, USA was forged. Interactions within Prof. YanoÃ†s laboratory at Kyoto University with scientists at all levels served as an unparalleled experience in which the fellow gained a better appreciation of the research environment, research community, and scientific policies of Japan. The fellow experienced the research culture and the spirit of innovation and precision in science, for which the Japanese are known. The introduction to the Japanese society, culture, and language through cultural activities proved to be unforgettable; old traditions going back to long before our country was founded, harmoniously present in the modern society. This research on cellulose and chitin nanofiber-reinforced materials contributes to an understanding of biopolymer reinforcement and the design of new hierarchically-structured materials from biopolymers. The results are furthermore expected to contribute to structure-property correlations for the design of porous materials with a hierarchical structure, such as those used in filtration, catalytic, energy storage, and tissue engineering applications.
